prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC5584 and NGC5496 CO(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To map 12CO(1-0) at 0.7" resolution, with 3 km/s representative bandwidth covering the region of the disk with IRAM 30m pointings. Get CN (n=1-0) lines for free which can constrain the density profile and PDR conditions. Free-free thermal radio emission may also be detected in the HII regions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect the line widths to be typically 10 km/s for the sources resolved at R=50 pc if they follow Larson's relations, although the fact that these galaxies have a clearly unusual ISM makes it difficult to predict a priori. However, the reason for our program is to find out why the molecular gas in our objects is so faint in CO and so we wish to be able to measure narrower linewidths, hence our chosen resolution of 1.5 km/s, which means we could measure velocity dispersions as low as 2 km/s. If the lines are narrow, then we would be detecting signal in 1.5 km/s bandwidth rather than the fiducial 3 km/s we have chosen for the time estimates. However, we would also expect a peak flux 2 times larger since the same integrated flux would be spread over fewer channels in the case of narrow lines. If on the other hand the lines are wider than 10 km/s, we will average over more channels to recover sufficient SNR for wider lines.

We wish to just resolve clouds with R ~37-50 pc which we can do with 0.7-1" angular resolution. The largest angular scale is 800-1000 pc (8") at the distances of the sources, and given the narrow linewidths in the single dish data on kpc scales we do not expect structures to extend on scales larger than this. If necessary we will taper the data slightly to recover lower surface brightness emission which is extended over several beams. We expect to have sufficient u-v coverage to detect the compact clumps and measure their properties and to assess the amount of more diffuse structure if it is present.

We derived estimated CO(1-0) peak fluxes using 2 main methods. (1) we used Larson's size-luminosity relation to predict the L(1-0) for a cloud with radius = 50pc (similar to those we expect to resolve). We then scaled this luminosity to a CO flux in Jy km/s using Lco = (3.25 x 10^7 *Sco* D^2)/nu_obs^2 where Sco is in Jy km/s, D in Mpc, and nu_obs in Ghz. We averaged the luminosity-linewidth relations from the Solomon 87 study of galactic GMCs (L(50)=4.5 x 10^5 K km/s pc^2) and that from Bolatto 08 study of GMCs in nearby galaxies (L(50)=1.6 x 10^5 K km/s pc^2). The predicted flux in Jy km/s was then divided by the expected line width of the cloud, again from Larson's relation, the velocity dispersion, sigma_v ~ 4-5 km/s, giving an expected FWHM of ~10 km/s. This gives the average flux in mJy expected for a cloud of R~50 pc at the distance of the source (for a top hat line profile). (2) We used our RAM 30m CO(1-0) measurements in a 22" beam as follows: we calculated the H2 mass surface density in our 22" beam from Sig(H2) = 6.25 x Ico x cos(i) (Schruba 2011). Our values thus corrected to face on ranged from 0.4-5.1 Msun pc^-2 for the sample, which is very low on kpc scales. For comparison the average over kpc scales in the interarm region of M51 is 34 Msun pc^-2. We used the ratio of our projected sigma_H2 to that in M51 and assumed that our lower average surface density was due to a smaller filling factor in these galaxies relative to M51. By doing so we estimated filling factors between 0.1-7% for the various locations. Our 22" 1-0 flux was then scaled by the filling factor to give the average flux per cloud, asuuming we are just resolving clouds at R=50pc. This was then divided by the 10 km/s fiduciual line-width to give the peak flux expected. Both of these methods, which are totally independent gave consistent answers to within a factor 2, and we took the lowest flux of the range to estimate our observing time.
Our peak expected fluxes are in the range 21-31 mJy across the two sources. We aim for a SNR=4 over 3 km/s representative bandwidth (or 1/3 of the linewidth), which requires an rms of 5.3 mJy per beam.
For free we also get two hyperfine lines of CN (n=1-0). This line is expected to be ~1/10 of CO(1-0), but is enhanced in PDR regions and so may indicate if a large fraction of the CO is in such regions. Smoothing and stacking data at CO(1-0) velocities should allow us to acheive global CN detections over various parts of the galaxy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC5584 CO(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mapping 12CO(2-1) across the disk covering the regions measured by IRAM at 0.7" resolution, in a 3 km/s representative bandwidth (but with smaller channels to be sensitive to narrower lines). We get C18O(2-1) for free and it may be detected in the brightest clumps or if the C810 abundance is unusually high due to the plethora of massive star formation in these galaxies. We can stack on 12CO(2-1) data to make gobal detections of the ratio. We do not expect to detect continuum except in very dense clumps or if there is substatial free-free contribution. Continuum is not a main aim of this SG.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect the line widths to be typically 10 km/s for the sources resolved at R=50 pc if they follow Larson's relations, although the fact that these galaxies have a clearly unusual ISM makes it difficult to predict a priori. However, the reason for our program is to find out why the molecular gas in our objects is so faint in CO and so we wish to be able to measure narrower linewidths, hence our chosen resolution of 1.5 km/s, which means we could measure velocity dispersions (sigma_v) as low as 2 km/s. If the lines are narrow, then we would be detecting signal in 1.5 km/s bandwidth rather than the fiducial 3 km/s we have chosen for the time estimates. However, we would also expect a peak flux 2 times larger since the same integrated flux would be spread over fewer channels in the case of narrow lines. If on the other hand the lines are wider than 10 km/s, we will average over more channels to recover sufficient SNR for wider lines.

We wish to just resolve clouds with R ~37-50 pc which we can do with 0.7-1" angular resolution. The largest angular scale is 800-1000 pc (8") at the distances of the sources, and given the narrow linewidths in the single dish data on kpc scales we do not expect structures to extend on scales larger than this. If necessary we will taper the data slightly to recover lower surface brightness emission which is extended over several beams. We expect to have sufficient u-v coverage to detect the compact clumps and measure their properties and to assess the amount of more diffuse structure if it is present.

We have used IRAM 30m to obtain CO(2-1) and CO(1-0) pointings on three regions in this galaxy. We derived estimated CO(2-1) peak fluxes using 2 main methods. (1) we used Larson's size-luminosity relation to predict the L(2-1) for a cloud with radius = 50pc (similar to those we expect to resolve), asumming L21/L10 = 0.8. We then scaled this luminosity to a CO flux in Jy km/s using Lco = (3.25 x 10^7 *Sco* D^2)/nu_obs^2 where Sco is in Jy km/s, D in Mpc, and nu_obs in Ghz. We averaged the luminosity-linewidth relations from the Solomon 87 study of galactic GMCs (L(50)=4.5 x 10^5 K km/s pc^2) and that from Bolatto 08 study of GMCs in nearby galaxies (L(50)=1.6 x 10^5 K km/s pc^2). The predicted flux in Jy km/s was then divided by the expected line width of the cloud, again from Larson's relation, the velocity dispersion, sigma_v ~ 4-5 km/s, giving an expected FWHM of ~10 km/s. This gives the average flux in mJy expected for a cloud of R~50 pc at the distance of the source (for a top hat line profile). (2) We used our IRAM 30m CO(2-1) measurements in an 11" beam as follows: we calculated the H2 mass surface density in our 22" beam from Sig(H2) = 6.25 x Ico x cos(i) (Schruba 2011). Our values thus corrected to face on ranged from 0.4-5.1 Msun pc^-2 for the sample, which is very low on kpc scales. For comparison the average over kpc scales in the interarm region of M51 is 34 Msun pc^-2. We used the ratio of our projected sigma_H2 to that in M51 and assumed that our lower average surface density was due to a smaller filling factor in these galaxies relative to M51. By doing so we estimated filling factors between 0.1-7% for the various locations. Our 11" 2-1 flux was then scaled by the filling factor to give the average flux per cloud, asuuming we are just resolving clouds at R=50pc. This was then divided by the 10 km/s fiduciual line-width to give the peak flux expected. Both of these methods, which are totally independent gave consistent answers to within a factor 2, and we took the lowest flux of the range to estimate our observing time.
Our peak expected fluxes are in the range 54-100 mJy. We aim for a min SNR=4 over 3 km/s representative bandwidth (or 1/3 of the linewidth), which requires an rms of 13.5 mJy per beam.
Since our mosaic more efficiently covers the area of our IRAM pointings as one larger recangle, we also will probe the more diffuse regions of the ISM in the galaxy and we can bin spectrally or spatially as required to recover any fainter signal in those areas. Ideally we would have included the 13CO(2-1) line in this SG but the tunings were not possible with enough bandwidth to be sure of recovering all the galaxy velocities, however, we have included the C18O(2-1) line. As our integration times are set based on detection of 12CO(2-1), we only expect to detect C18O(2-1) in the brightest clumps but we will also be able to stack at the CO(2-1) and HI velocities in order to try to recover global ratios. This line is not a key driver at this time.
Extrapolating the dust fluxes from Herschel using the global fitted SED and the same filling factor arguments we find that the 1.2mm continuum is likely to be fainter than we can detect unless there is a flattening of the dust spectrum at longer wavelengths due to changes in emissitity index or addition from thermal free-free in SF regions. If there is a more diffuse component of dust, then we may be able to recover that by slightly tapering the data. This will be a bonus if present.

We can stack on 12CO(2-1) data to make gobal detections of the ratio. We do not expect to detect continuum except in very dense clumps or if there is substatial free-free contribution. Continuum is not a main aim of this SG.

Both of these methods, which are totally independent gave consistent answers to within a factor 2, and we took the lowest flux of the range to estimate our observing time.
Our peak expected fluxes are in the range 35-90 mJy. We aim for a min SNR=4 over 3 km/s representative bandwidth (or 1/3 of the linewidth), which requires an rms of 8.8 mJy per beam.
Since our mosaic more efficiently covers the area of our IRAM pointings as one larger recangle, we also will probe the more diffuse regions of the ISM in the galaxy and we can bin spectrally or spatially as required to recover any fainter signal in those areas. If there is a more diffuse component of dust, then we may be able to recover that by slightly tapering the data. This will be a bonus if present.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC5584 CO(3-2) and dust emission
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To map the CO(3-2) and cold dust emission at 0.7" resolution across the same region as CO(2-1). Get HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) for free so that we can constrain the density structure of the molecular gas.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We want the maximum bandwidth over which to measure continuum, so we have set the correlators to their lowest spectral resolution, which is ~1 km/s. We have binned our channels by a factor of 2 to reduce data rates.
We expect the line widths to be typically 10 km/s for the sources resolved at R=50 pc if they follow Larson's relations, although the fact that these galaxies have a clearly unusual ISM makes it difficult to predict a priori. However, the reason for our program is to find out why the molecular gas in our objects is so faint in CO and so we wish to be able to measure narrower linewidths, hence our chosen resolution of 1 km/s, which means we could measure velocity dispersions as low as 2 km/s. If the lines *are* narrow, then we would be detecting signal in ~1 km/s bandwidth rather than the fiducial 3 km/s we have chosen for the time estimates. However, we would also expect a higher peak flux since the same predicted integrated flux would be spread over fewer channels in the case of narrow lines. If on the other hand the lines are wider than 10 km/s, we will average over more channels to recover sufficient SNR for wider lines.

We wish to just resolve clouds with R ~37-50 pc which we can do with 0.7-1" angular resolution. The largest angular scale is 800-1000 pc (8") at the distances of the sources, and given the narrow linewidths in the single dish data on kpc scales we do not expect CO structures to extend on scales larger than this. If necessary we will taper the data slightly to recover lower surface brightness emission which is extended over several beams. We expect to have sufficient u-v coverage to detect the compact clumps and measure their properties and to assess the amount of more diffuse structure if it is present. Of course the dust may not have a purely clumpy distrubution and one of the main purposes of the project is to determine the dust morphology to better understand the radiative transfer in these galaxies. With this sensitivity and resolution we can progressively taper and compare to the single dish 850 maps to work out the fractions and scales of clumpy and diffuse emission. If the emission were purely diffuse (unlikely worst case scenario) then we would need to taper to 4" to recover it at 3 sigma per beam.

There are three goals to this SG: 1) to detect the continuum and determine the relationship between dust and CO emission, and the spatial distribution of dust clumps relative to optical extinction features 2) to measure the CO(3-2) emission to trace regions of higher excitation gas and 3) to detect or put limits on the HCO+(4-3)/HCN(4-3), giving us a probe of the dense gas.
The time estimation is based on detecting the continuum, but also gives us the line sensitivity to probe R31 (luminosity ratio) down to a ratio of 0.1 and to probe HCO+(4-3)/HCN(4-3) in the brighter clumps.
Continuum sensitivity: Using our Herschel and SCUBA2 observations, we know that 100 mJy/beam at 250 mic with Herschel is roughly 3.2 mJy/beam with SCUBA2. The min 250mic surface brightness in the region of interest is >250 mJy/beam and so the min 850mic surface brightness expected in a 15" beam is 8 mJy/beam. If this is located in the same clumps we have assumed for the CO lines (see tech case to CO(1-0)) then the peak flux per clump (=per beam for clumps matching beam) will be 0.75 mJy. We aim to detect this with a significance of 4-5.
CO(3-2) primary line. Given our continuum sensitivity requirements, we will be able to measure the CO(3-2) line at high fidelity and SNR. This line will provide information on gas density and temperature conditions and the ratio of 3-2/2-1 and 3-2/1-0 will provide information on which clouds are star forming. We have estimated the peak line brightness using our CO(1-0) observations and R31=0.34 (where R31 = S32/S10 * (nu_10/nu_32)^2). The R31 value comes from weak CO(3-2) detection for the centre of N5584 using shallow HARP data (Bourne et al. 2013). The predicted S32 using the CO(1-0) in a 22" beam was then scaled to the ALMA resolution using the same arguments about filling factor as used for the CO(1-0) data.
The CO(3-2) peak brightness expected is 75 mJy/beam. We will achieve very high SNR on the line (>10 in a 3km/s channel) for a R31 > 0.34, and because of this we can probe to much lower R31 ratios. For a 5 sigma detection in 1/3 of the linewidth we would be sensitive to a ratio R31 = 0.06. For high R31 ratios we will be sensitive to intrinsically less luminous L10 clouds.
We will have another FDM window covering the HCO+(4-3) and HCN(4-3) lines which are dense gas tracers. This typically has a value 1/10th or less that of the CO(3-2) line, based on data we have for IR luminous galaxies (Zhang). For bright regions of CO(3-2) gas, we should be able to probe the dense gas properties where R31>0.4 and CO(3-2)/HCO+ < 10. Alternatively, we can estimate the Lir in the IRAM pointings using our Herschel data, and use the relations between Lir and HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) for star forming galaxies in Zhang 2014 to make rough estimates of the LHCN and LHCO+ in those regions. For the same scaling assumptions on filling factor as used to determine CO(2-1) and CO(1-0) fluxes we expect S_HCN and S_HCO+ in the range 2-23 mJy peak. We may thus detect some brighter, denser clumps individually, and will be able to stack using CO(3-2) velocities to recover average properties.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UGC 9215 and UGC9299 CO(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To map 12CO(1-0) at 0.7" resolution, with 3 km/s representative bandwidth covering the region of the disk with IRAM 30m pointings. Get CN (n=1-0) lines for free which can constrain the density profile and PDR conditions. Free-free thermal radio emission may also be detected in the HII regions.

This gives the average flux in mJy expected for a cloud of R~50 pc at the distance of the source (for a top hat line profile). (2) We used our RAM 30m CO(1-0) measurements in a 22" beam as follows: we calculated the H2 mass surface density in our 22" beam from Sig(H2) = 6.25 x Ico x cos(i) (Schruba 2011). Our values thus corrected to face on ranged from 0.4-5.1 Msun pc^-2 for the sample, which is very low on kpc scales. For comparison the average over kpc scales in the interarm region of M51 is 34 Msun pc^-2. We used the ratio of our projected sigma_H2 to that in M51 and assumed that our lower average surface density was due to a smaller filling factor in these galaxies relative to M51. By doing so we estimated filling factors between 0.1-7% for the various locations. Our 22" 1-0 flux was then scaled by the filling factor to give the average flux per cloud, asuuming we are just resolving clouds at R=50pc. This was then divided by the 10 km/s fiduciual line-width to give the peak flux expected. Both of these methods, which are totally independent gave consistent answers to within a factor 2, and we took the lowest flux of the range to estimate our observing time.
Our peak expected fluxes are in the range 16-21 mJy across the two sources. We aim for a SNR=4 over 3 km/s representative bandwidth (or 1/3 of the linewidth), which requires an rms of 4.0 mJy per beam.
For free we also get two hyperfine lines of CN (n=1-0. This line is expected to be ~1/10 of CO(1-0), but is enhanced in PDR regions and so may indicate if a large fraction of the CO is in such regions. Smoothing and stacking data at CO(1-0) velocities should allow us to acheive global CN detections over various parts of the galaxy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC5496 CO(3-2) and dust emission
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To map the CO(3-2) and cold dust emission at 0.7" resolution across the same region as CO(2-1). Get HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) for free so that we can constrain the density structure of the molecular gas.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We want the maximum bandwidth over which to measure continuum, so we have set the correlators to their lowest spectral resolution, which is ~1 km/s. We have binned our channels by a factor of 2 to reduce data rates.
We expect the line widths to be typically 10 km/s for the sources resolved at R=50 pc if they follow Larson's relations, although the fact that these galaxies have a clearly unusual ISM makes it difficult to predict a priori. However, the reason for our program is to find out why the molecular gas in our objects is so faint in CO and so we wish to be able to measure narrower linewidths, hence our chosen resolution of 1 km/s, which means we could measure velocity dispersions as low as 2 km/s. If the lines *are* narrow, then we would be detecting signal in ~1 km/s bandwidth rather than the fiducial 3 km/s we have chosen for the time estimates. However, we would also expect a higher peak flux since the same predicted integrated flux would be spread over fewer channels in the case of narrow lines. If on the other hand the lines are wider than 10 km/s, we will average over more channels to recover sufficient SNR for wider lines.

We wish to just resolve clouds with R ~37-50 pc which we can do with 0.7-1" angular resolution. The largest angular scale is 800-1000 pc (8") at the distances of the sources, and given the narrow linewidths in the single dish data on kpc scales we do not expect CO structures to extend on scales larger than this. If necessary we will taper the data slightly to recover lower surface brightness emission which is extended over several beams. We expect to have sufficient u-v coverage to detect the compact clumps and measure their properties and to assess the amount of more diffuse structure if it is present. Of course the dust may not have a purely clumpy distrubution and one of the main purposes of the project is to determine the dust morphology to better understand the radiative transfer in these galaxies. With this sensitivity and resolution we can progressively taper and compare to the single dish 850 maps to work out the fractions and scales of clumpy and diffuse emission. If the emission were purely diffuse (unlikely worst case scenario) then we would need to taper to 4" to recover it at 3 sigma per beam.

There are three goals to this SG: 1) to detect the continuum and determine the relationship between dust and CO emission, and the spatial distribution of dust clumps relative to optical extinction features 2) to measure the CO(3-2) emission to trace regions of higher excitation gas and 3) to detect or put limits on the HCO+(4-3)/HCN(4-3), giving us a probe of the dense gas.
The time estimation is based on detecting the continuum, but also gives us the line sensitivity to probe R31 (luminosity ratio) down to a ratio of 0.1 and to probe HCO+(4-3)/HCN(4-3) in the brighter clumps.
Continuum sensitivity: Using our Herschel and SCUBA2 observations, we know that 100 mJy/beam at 250 mic with Herschel is roughly 3.2 mJy/beam with SCUBA2. The min 250mic surface brightness in the region of interest is >250 mJy/beam and so the min 850mic surface brightness expected in a 15" beam is 8 mJy/beam. If this is located in the same clumps we have assumed for the CO lines (see tech case to CO(1-0)) then the peak flux per clump (=per beam for clumps matching beam) will be 0.65 mJy. We aim to detect this with a significance of 4-5.
CO(3-2) primary line. Given our continuum sensitivity requirements, we will be able to measure the CO(3-2) line at high fidelity and SNR. This line will provide information on gas density and temperature conditions and the ratio of 3-2/2-1 and 3-2/1-0 will provide information on which clouds are star forming. We have estimated the peak line brightness using our CO(1-0) observations and R31=0.34 (where R31 = S32/S10 * (nu_10/nu_32)^2). The R31 value comes from weak CO(3-2) detection for the centre of N5584 using shallow HARP data (Bourne et al. 2013). The predicted S32 using the CO(1-0) in a 22" beam was then scaled to the ALMA resolution using the same arguments about filling factor as used for the CO(1-0) data.
The CO(3-2) peak brightness expected is 68 mJy/beam. We will achieve very high SNR on the line (>10 in a 3km/s channel) for a R31 > 0.34, and because of this we can probe to much lower R31 ratios. For a 5 sigma detection in 1/3 of the linewidth we would be sensitive to a ratio R31 = 0.06. For high R31 ratios we will be sensitive to intrinsically less luminous L10 clouds.
We will have another FDM window covering the HCO+(4-3) and HCN(4-3) lines which are dense gas tracers. This typically has a value 1/10th or less that of the CO(3-2) line, based on data we have for IR luminous galaxies (Zhang). For bright regions of CO(3-2) gas, we should be able to probe the dense gas properties where R31>0.4 and CO(3-2)/HCO+ < 10. Alternatively, we can estimate the Lir in the IRAM pointings using our Herschel data, and use the relations between Lir and HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) for star forming galaxies in Zhang 2014 to make rough estimates of the LHCN and LHCO+ in those regions. For the same scaling assumptions on filling factor as used to determine CO(2-1) and CO(1-0) fluxes we expect S_HCN and S_HCO+ in the range 2-23 mJy peak. We may thus detect some brighter, denser clumps individually, and will be able to stack using CO(3-2) velocities to recover average properties.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UGC9215 and UGC9299 CO(3-2) and dust emission
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To map the CO(3-2) and cold dust emission at 0.7" resolution across the same region as CO(2-1). Get HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) for free so that we can constrain the density structure of the molecular gas.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We want the maximum bandwidth over which to measure continuum, so we have set the correlators to their lowest spectral resolution, which is ~1 km/s. We have binned our channels by a factor of 2 to reduce data rates.
We expect the line widths to be typically 10 km/s for the sources resolved at R=50 pc if they follow Larson's relations, although the fact that these galaxies have a clearly unusual ISM makes it difficult to predict a priori. However, the reason for our program is to find out why the molecular gas in our objects is so faint in CO and so we wish to be able to measure narrower linewidths, hence our chosen resolution of 1 km/s, which means we could measure velocity dispersions as low as 2 km/s. However, we would also expect a higher peak flux since the same predicted integrated flux would be spread over fewer channels in the case of narrow lines. If on the other hand the lines are wider than 10 km/s, we will average over more channels to recover sufficient SNR for wider lines.

e wish to just resolve clouds with R ~37-50 pc which we can do with 0.7-1" angular resolution. The largest angular scale is 800-1000 pc (8") at the distances of the sources, and given the narrow linewidths in the single dish data on kpc scales we do not expect CO structures to extend on scales larger than this. The time estimation is based on detecting the continuum, but also gives us the line sensitivity to probe R31 (luminosity ratio) down to a ratio of 0.1 and to probe HCO+(4-3)/HCN(4-3) in the brighter clumps.
Continuum sensitivity: Using our Herschel and SCUBA2 observations, we know that 100 mJy/beam at 250 mic with Herschel is roughly 3.2 mJy/beam with SCUBA2. The min 250mic surface brightness in the region of interest is >250 mJy/beam and so the min 850mic surface brightness expected in a 15" beam is 8 mJy/beam. If this is located in the same clumps we have assumed for the CO lines (see tech case to CO(1-0)) then the peak flux per clump (=per beam for clumps matching beam) will be 0.5 mJy. We aim to detect this with a significance of 4-5.
CO(3-2) primary line. Given our continuum sensitivity requirements, we will be able to measure the CO(3-2) line at high fidelity and SNR. This line will provide information on gas density and temperature conditions and the ratio of 3-2/2-1 and 3-2/1-0 will provide information on which clouds are star forming. We have estimated the peak line brightness using our CO(1-0) observations and R31=0.34 (where R31 = S32/S10 * (nu_10/nu_32)^2). The R31 value comes from weak CO(3-2) detection for the centre of N5584 using shallow HARP data (Bourne et al. 2013). The predicted S32 using the CO(1-0) in a 22" beam was then scaled to the ALMA resolution using the same arguments about filling factor as used for the CO(1-0) data.
The CO(3-2) peak brightness expected is 52-68 mJy/beam. We will achieve very high SNR on the line (>10 in a 3km/s channel) for a R31 > 0.34, and because of this we can probe to much lower R31 ratios. For a 5 sigma detection in 1/3 of the linewidth we would be sensitive to a ratio R31 = 0.1. For high R31 ratios we will be sensitive to intrinsically less luminous L10 clouds.
We will have another FDM window covering the HCO+(4-3) and HCN(4-3) lines which are dense gas tracers. This typically has a value 1/10th or less that of the CO(3-2) line, based on data we have for IR luminous galaxies (Zhang). For bright regions of CO(3-2) gas, we should be able to probe the dense gas properties where R31>0.4 and CO(3-2)/HCO+ < 10. Alternatively, we can estimate the Lir in the IRAM pointings using our Herschel data, and use the relations between Lir and HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) for star forming galaxies in Zhang 2014 to make rough estimates of the LHCN and LHCO+ in those regions. For the same scaling assumptions on filling factor as used to determine CO(2-1) and CO(1-0) fluxes we expect S_HCN and S_HCO+ in the range 2-23 mJy peak. We may thus detect some brighter, denser clumps individually, and will be able to stack using CO(3-2) velocities to recover average properties.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We have discovered a very nearby population of extremely blue galaxies with Log M* = 7.5-9.5 Msun and high gas fractions (50-95%) that also have the highest specific dust masses of any local population. They have extended and clumpy starformation and H2/dust ratios over an order of magnitude lower than typical star forming spiral galaxies, depsite reasonably high metallicities (0.8Zsun). Their inferred molecular gas depletion times are ~250 Myr, overlapping with those in LIRGs and ULIRGs but at ?100 lower LIR. Instead, these sources represent a far more common phase of galaxy evolution; comprising more than half the galaxies discovered in the Herschel- ATLAS local volume sample. They are full of paradoxes - dusty but transparent, UV bright but with cold dust and high gas fraction but high enrichment. We will explore their dust properties, CO dark gas components, the effects of cosmic rays on CO, disk stability and conditions for H2 formation. Our ALMA observations will probe diffuse and dense gas tracers and dust emission on GMC scales (~70 pc) revealing the secrets of these gas rich and potentially unstable disks.
